message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: private static boolean isValid(String accountLine) throws BankAccountException {
    StringTokenizer strTok = new StringTokenizer(accountLine, ";");
    boolean valid = true;
    
    if(strTok.countTokens() == 2) {
        String firstToken = strTok.nextToken();
        String secondToken = strTok.nextToken();
        
        if(firstToken.length() == 10 && !firstToken.matches(".*[0-9].*")) {
            if(!secondToken.matches(".*[0-9].*")) {
                valid = true;
            } else {
                valid = false;
            }
        } else {
            valid = false;
        }
    } else {
        System.out.println("Invalid Bank Account info. " + strTok.nextToken());
        valid = false;
    }
    
    return valid;
}
<<<explanation>>>: To check the first or the second token, you can use the StringTokenizer.nextToken() method. In your code, you can assign the first token to a variable using strTok.nextToken() and assign the second token to another variable using strTok.nextToken(). Then you can perform the necessary checks on these variables. In the provided code, the first token is assigned to the variable firstToken and the second token is assigned to the variable secondToken. The checks for the first and second tokens are then performed using these variables.
